_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:

Bayport will be a Zero injury and Zero release workplace.
Environmental, health, and safety are higher priority than production for everyone.
Everyone is responsible.
Everyone will adhere to Corporate EHS principles.
Everyone will show this by their behaviors.
Violations of EHS policies, rules, and procedures will not be tolerated by anyone at the Bayport Plant.
We must all hold ourselves and each other accountable.

The Bayport Plant Environment Policy states:

At the  Bayport Plant we strive to continuously improve our environmental, health, safety and security (EHS) performance with a goal to be a Zero injury and Zero release workplace.  This commitment is supported by our EHS Management System (RC/EHSMS) and annual commitments to improvement objectives for significant EHS aspects of our operation.  The following summarizes the core beliefs and principles which underlies our commitment:

    We will adhere to the Rohm and Haas Company, Environmental, Health and Safety and Sustainable Development (EHS    SD) Principles, applicable Rohm and Haas EHS Standards and the Monomers Business EHS&SD Principles and Policy.  Additionally, we will adhere to the American Chemistry Council (ACC) Guiding Principles and the Responsible Care Management System (RCMS) Technical Specifications.
    We will operate in compliance with applicable laws, permits and regulation.
    We will conduct periodic reviews and audits of our RC/EHSMS to ensure conformance with these standards.
    EHS performance targets and goals will be set on an annual basis and periodically reviewed.
    The Bayport Management Team is responsible for implementing the RC/EHSMS and providing resources to accomplish its requirements.
    All employees, contractors and vendors are responsible for improving Environmental, Health and Safety performance in their areas and for conducting their activities in conformance with the RC/EHSMS.
    All employees will be trained to pr

operly conduct their activities in safe, and environmentally responsible manner and to ensure appropriate operational security.
    We will maintain dialogue with employees, regulating agencies and the community concerning our EHS performance.
    Significant EHS incidents will be investigated and communicated to employees.
    Violations of EHS policies, rules, and procedures will not be tolerated by anyone at the Bayport Plant. E will hold ourselves  and each other accountable.

In addition we have environmental and safety "cardinal rules" that cover proper operation of pollution control equipment, data integrity, reporting of all spills and releases, and change management for all process revisions. 

Bayport Facility and Chemicals Handled:

The Bayport plant is a chemical manufacturing facility. Primary products are specialty monomers and biocides. End use applications range from contact lenses and cosmetics to oil field drilling fluids.

We handle ethylene oxide and propylene oxide in 165,000 lb. rail cars.


Worst Case Release Scenario:

Our worst case scenario is a catastophic release of 183,000  lbs of Ethylene Oxide (EO) from a 165,000 lbs rail car which is connected to a weigh tank holding 18,000 lbs of EO.  Using RMP Comp, with a release duration of 10 minutes and a release rate of 18,300 lbs per minute, this release would have a toxic impact of 12 miles.

Alternative Case Release Scenarios:

For ethylene oxide and propylene oxide the alternative release scenarios are failure of our air pollution control device. With detection (process control instrumentation) and response (shut down of unit operation) neither of  the 3750 lb. releases travel off site, and thus no residences are impacted.

Accidental Release Prevention Programs:

Included in the Bayport plant?s accidental release prevention plans are fully automated processes with level and flow measurement and control, minimum inventories of chemicals, excess flow control valves, automatic emergency shut-off valve

s, redundant safety interlocks, preventative maintenance programs, chemical detectors, remotely operated valves to isolate and minimize a release, and annual training of employees. 

Included in the Bayport plant?s emergency response program are fully trained exterior and interior fire brigade, fully trained Technician level HAZMAT team for both onsite and offsite response, fully trained Emergency Medical Technician Basic team, fully trained High Angle and Confined Space Rescue team, fully trained incident commanders, onsite fire truck with foam capability, onsite mobile equipment for HAZMAT response, member CIMA (Channel Industry Mutual Aid), water spray deluge systems, sewer spill isolation valves and catch basin, notification systems including plant wide notification and portable radios, neighbor and community notification procedures including use of CAER line, and chemical detectors strategically located. 


Five Year Accident History:

We have had no reportable releases of covered chemicals in the last 5 years.


Emergency Response Program:

Our emergency response efforts are coordinated with CIMA (Channel Industry Mutual Aid), La Porte LEPC, and area industrial neighbors (we have a reciprocal plan to share fire water with the Good Year plant across the road from us). Our emergency plans are reviewed at least annually. Our public notification system consists of calling the LEPC, State of Texas, Harris County, CAER line, and industrial neighbors.


Planned Changes to Safety Program

HAZOP's for our various processes are frequently updated.
